Tokyo Story is an evocative and very personal film that is a wonderful example of the nuanced emotions that one can feel when viewing a film by a master of their craft. Yasujiro Ozu is now considered one of the greatest filmmakers in the history of cinema, of course he wasn't internationally praised until nearly seven years after his death. Akira Kurosawa and Kenji Mizoguchi were both more well known at the time than Ozu for a variety of reasons. The most prominent reason was that distributors thought his films were "too Japanese", by that they meant that the traditional customs and way of life in Japan wouldn't be understood or appreciated in the West or other places besides Japan. The films of Ozu were gathered and shown after his death to great critical acclaim and one thing was certain with all his films, they are universal in their themes and messages. His films touch on everyday problems and issues concerning everyday people and situations, most involving a family dynamic or some other type of close relationship.
In Tokyo Story we see the lives of an elderly couple as they travel very far in order to visit their busy children living in the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. The film is comprised of a week or so of everyday life for the people involved and tells a beautiful, albeit very sad and contemplative story of appreciating one's elders, family especially, as they won't be around forever. The film's emphasis is on spending the time left wisely and lovingly. The story is so simplistic in it's narrative and filmed as if the camera is merely observing unobtrusively. Many sequences are shot as if the cameraman is kneeling down and the effect is both thoroughly personal and restrained. No single character is emphasized or framed differently in order to keep the feeling of intimacy and keeps the viewer simply a passive observer. Ozu let's hit character and their actions be the movement as he uses very little movement on the part of the camera, taking great care in setting up his shot well in advance. While simple from a visual and narrative perspective, it's Ozu's personal and emotional touch that elevates his works above so many of his contemporaries.

Sentimental without being maudlin, touching without being manipulative, Tokyo Story is Yasujiro Ozu's masterpiece about the passage of time and the inevitable disintegration of the nuclear family as children begin to carve their own paths in life.  It's the simple story of an elderly couple who travel to Tokyo to visit their children and come to the sobering realization that they have started to become a burden to their offspring.  Presented in Ozu's unique style of low stationary camera angles, perfectly framed shots, and beautifully blocked scenes, it is a meditative tale of life and death, a classic worthy of the praise that has been heaped on it over the years.

"Tokyo Story" is a long movie, and it must be admitted that the viewer may feel its length. Trivialities aside, it is hard not to be awed by the incredibly well-rounded scope of the film's vast and yet quietly understated ambitions. Through the seemingly leisurely format of an elderly couple visiting their adult children in Tokyo, Ozu evokes an epic vision of inter-generational conflict, the bittersweet transience of life (mono no aware), and generally pervasive human frailties in a fashion that merely observes with empathy without deigning to comment. Furthermore, these achievements occur in the context of a naturalistic depiction of life that upholds its dignity through eschewing the melodrama of artificial manipulation. On account of this strength, the film can prove a culture shock to the new initiate while requiring a degree of patience from even the most devoted viewer, yet it would be substantially false to regard "Tokyo Story" as more of a challenge than a pleasure. Its quiet regard for humanity and all of its concurrent good intentions and personal failings leaves us in tears and inspires us (without preaching) to treasure our own interpersonal relationships that we've come to take for granted. Although made in post-war Japan, the film feels destined to remain timeless and universal, securing its place within the pantheon of those greatest works which touch deeply upon the relevant themes of life which we should all care so much about.

An interesting fact about Ozu is that he was one of the first director's to break the 180 rule (a filming guideline that two characters in a scene should maintain the same left/right relationship to one another); and I think he breaks it to great effect. When he depicts dialogue scenes he doesn't simply use the shoulder/reverse technique, but instead opts to focus directly in on his actors faces. This is important because in this film, the actors' performances are intentionally dialed down to increase the realism of the piece. So when his characters speak, Ozu uses this close-up shot to let the viewer examine the character and pull out the more subtle emotional nuance from the performance. And that method works to an amazing degree in this film because the entire story revolves around the fading relationships between the young and the old, and how in a modern world, family can drift apart. When the young characters talk to the old ones, rarely do they say anything of substance to each other. Most of the interactions between the grandparents and their children is filled with feigned niceties, forced concern, and surface level small talk. The notable exception to this is the relationship between the grandparents and the widow of their deceased son, which is quite close and intimate. And that is one of the great ironies of the story, as noted by the grandfather: Out of all the people in the family, the only one who shows any deep caring towards the older generation is the one who isn't related by blood. And this is Ozu's way of shining a light on the society of the modern world and more specifically post-war Japan. It isn't a critique or a praise, he is simply saying that the times are changing. No longer does family necessitate warmth and love, care is something to be received from the caring. And this is why Ozu's cinematography is so crucial to the themes of the film: it allows us to see through the feigned niceties. For example, the daughter of the main characters is nothing but polite in her dialogue. In fact, if we only read her lines in a screenplay she would seem like a devoted daughter, but when Ozu isolates her face in the frame, and shows her in close-up, we can tell there is no emotion behind her words, and that her caring is a mere polite facade. The widow of the deceased son on the other hand is quite the opposite. The words she says are - for the most part - quite similar to what the daughter says, but when Ozu lets us examine her face, we can tell from her eyes and expressions that she truly does care for her parent-in-laws. Another technique Ozu utilizes is his intricate framing. When Ozu shoots a scene it is usually framed through the context of the surroundings. We often see shots through doorways and hallways, or between two objects. And when Ozu frames these scenes he doesn't use cuts to jump around the frame, instead he holds the shot and lets us observe the scene, letting the actors shift the frame instead of the camera. By doing this, Ozu allows the viewer to examine the scene through an impartial lens. We see what's happening and are permitted to observe how the characters interact and talk. And this works to great effect in understanding the relationship in how each character feels toward each other. There is a scene in which the grandmother tries to show love towards her grandson, which he responds to by running out of the room, and subsequently the frame. But instead of cutting to where the boy is running to or shifting directly to the next scene, Ozu lingers on the existing frame, showing the grandmother alone in the room. We, as the viewers, can see that the grandma is isolated from her family. Though every interaction she has is pleasant, there is no love. The adults can hide their lack of intimacy behind pleasantness, but the child, immature in nature, is not old enough to obscure his inner feelings, runs away from his grandmother. And you can tell she feels this invisible distance, just by her standing alone in a frame.

The depth that Ozu's cinematography creates is the pinnacle of what Hitchcock called "pure cinema". There is much more to be said about his filmography and why it's so artful, but the way in which he blends theme and function is what stands out to me the most. By doing less with the camera, Ozu achieves unprecedented depth. And that's what makes this film a masterpiece.

Tokyo Story is a story about the collapse of the ie, the traditional Japanese family structure, in the face of modernization. However, this topic is explored in such a way that it remains relevant 65 years later and half a world away. The portrayal of a group of siblings so absorbed in their own problems to spend time with their elderly parents is sufficiently relatable that it made me feel deeply guilty for neglecting to spend more time with my grandparents. The writing and structure prevent the film from feeling exploitative or sentimental, and the actors deliver beautifully understated performances, effectively conveying the subtexts underlying much of the dialogue. The movie is also expertly shot, with a rather distinctive style where the camera seldom moves and is placed lower than is typical for dialogue scenes. Breaking established conventions regarding cinematography can be risky, but Yasujiro Ozu is has sufficient skill to make this something akin to the signature style of an esteemed painter rather than the distracting misuse of the Dutch angle in Battlefield Earth. With its lack of much in the way of an overarching plot or defining events, Tokyo Story is a film I appreciate more than I enjoy, but viewing the film gave me the intense sense that I was watching something special.

Superficially it might look slow, but I think it is perfectly edited. Each scene effectively makes a point that adds to the story and moves it forward. Visually, many shots are well composed. And the best part, I think, is that it is very evocative without melodrama. That's a huge contrast with most popular movies that rely on sensational drama and exaggerated characters. This movie skips all of that, and yet the more you think about it, the more you feel its depth.

Tokyo Story is a scathing indictment of how people mistreat their parents and take them for granted as they grow older. At least I think that was the point of the film. Most of the time I was too busy trying to stay awake, because it is such an uneventful and bland movie. It’s a slice-of-life drama, and any time I use that as a description for a film, it probably means I hated it because I was bored. The older couple are sweet, and they had one nice daughter-in-law, but otherwise most of the characters were annoying and forgettable. This movie also pushed my limits of remembering Japanese names, because I could not keep track of who they were talking about half the time. There isn’t much flow to the story, in fact there are often simple cuts from one scene to another where it is suddenly revealed that days or weeks have passed during that cut between scenes. It makes the whole film seem disjointed and odd. Although nothing is quite as unusual as the way Ozu shoots all the conversations. We are constantly bombarded by moments where someone talks directly to camera in the middle of a conversation. Instead of shooting over the shoulder of the person who’s being spoken to (as most filmmakers would do) we are put in the position of that person as someone talks directly at us. Then it will switch back to a wide shot where we see everyone in the room, then to another person looking at the camera, and so on. Not only does it look weird, but it also takes away any normal flow to the conversation because you can tell there was a cut as they repositioned cameras setting up for the next sentence. It was such a conscious choice that I kept wondering why Ozu chose to film scenes in that fashion, so it took me out of the film. I did not enjoy Tokyo Story at all, but clearly I’m missing something because it is a well-loved movie for many people, it’s just not for me.

Our Daily Free Stream: Ozu - Tokyo Story (engl. subt.). Zum Tod von Setsuko Hara: Ihr Lächeln, wie ein wehmütiges Eingeständnis mit dem Leben. Ihr Gespür für flüchtige Gesten führen uns in die Welt der leisen Zwischentöne. Sie war das Gesicht des japanischen Kinos und als Schauspielerin prädestiniert für die Kunst Ozus. Aus diesem Anlass zeigen wir heute Tokyo Story. - Keine Geschichte könnte einfacher sein: Die Grosseltern reisen in die Stadt, ihre Kinder und Enkelkinder zu besuchen. Die allerdings sind beschäftigt, was die alten Menschen verärgert. Still, ohne dass es jemand zugibt, verfehlt der Besuch seinen Zweck eines Miteinanders. Nach der Rückkehr stirbt die Grossmutter wenige Tage später und nun ist es an den Kindern, eine Reise zu unternehmen. Aus diesen Elementen hat Ozu einen der grössten Filme aller Zeiten gemacht; eine Geschichte, die noch lange nachwirkt und tiefe Emotionen weckt. Tokyo Story ignoriert die Momente, die andere Filme gesucht hätten: Die grossen Kino-Szenen. Er will nicht unsere Gefühle verstärken, sondern Verständnis erregen. Tokyo Story erreicht das in einem Masse, dass ich nahezu während des gesamten Finales heulen musste und mir sicher war: Ja, dieser Film kann uns ein wenig Erkenntnis bringen und einige Schritte weiter weg führen von unseren Fehlern! Die Charaktere sind universal angelegt, fast scheint es so, als blicke man in einen Spiegel. Ozus Drama stellt unsere Natur bloss. Es ist nicht einfach so, dass wir uns von unseren Familien entfremdet hätten. Wir verschanzen uns vor ihnen, um uns den Fragen des Lebens nach Liebe, Arbeit und Tod nicht zu stellen. Doch diese Flucht in Floskeln und Ablenkung - ein japanischer Film, der mittlerweile über 60 Jahre alt ist, deckt das alles auf! Ozu erweist sich nicht nur als grosser Regisseur, sondern auch als erfolgreicher Lehrer, denn sein Film wird zum Freund. Tokyo Story eröffnet mit bittersüsser Musik, die aber nie zum Zweck eingesetzt wird, unseren Affekt zu erhaschen. Ozu liebt Wolken, Rauch und leere Strassen, wie kein anderer Regisseur erweckt er mit jeder Einstellung meine Zuneigung. Seine Kamera bewegt sich fast immer auf Augenhöhe der Protagonisten und wird nahezu nie bewegt. Jede Einstellung wirkt wie eine eigene Komposition, fast möchte man sie als Bild rahmen. Ozu liebt die Stille, Bewegung wird immer nur durch die Figuren erzeugt. Der Grossvater lächelt viel, wenn er zuhört - schliesslich antwortet er "Ja". In seinem Blick aber sehen wir, dass das Gesagte nicht dem entspricht, was er meint. Vielmehr spüren wir, wie er sich davor schützt, seine wahren Gefühle zu offenbaren. "Ja" drückt auch die Reue darüber aus. Manchmal entdeckt Ozu Details im Bild wie die wunderschöne Teekanne. Fast ist es so, als ob die Kamera sie gefunden hätte und nun präsentiert. Wenn die Familien-Mitglieder beisammen sitzen, sehen wir meistens mehrere im Bild. Gefühle werden in ihren Gesprächen verschlüsselt, selbst übertriebene Bekundungen sind nur zum Zweck des Verbergens da. Während des Begräbnisses der Grossmutter versammelt sich die Familie und wieder sehen wir sie vor uns - in einer Reihe. Diesmal aber sind ihre Tränen echt. I always find movies that are deemed 'classics' to be quite fascinating. Some films have truly stood the test of time and still remain as relevant today as they were in their own time. When I got round to watching Tokyo Story, I have to say, I didn't see what all the fuss was about. Yes, I completely understand the films messages, and its theme of familial estrangement is a topic that will never cease to be relevant. But the truth is I've seen other movies that address this issue much better, most notably would be the Jack Nicholson drama About Schmidt. Even in the movie Birdman, despite it being something of a sub-plot, it was more resonant and affecting because in both of these cases I felt much more of a connection to the characters who experience these feelings. The pacing in Tokyo Story is far too leisurely, and while some of the dialogue is very poignant and even quite melancholy, most of the actors don't look sad or disappointed, they look bored. When you combine this with the camera-work, which is to say that it never moves during a scene, simply cutting back and forth and filming from near the ground, the film achieves virtually no fluidity or forward momentum. Maybe this is intentional, and is supposed to put us in the main characters state of almost living purgatory, but it made me feel like I was watching a wooden, poorly acted and clumsily assembled set of clips taken from a handful of cameras a person had simply left round their house to film whatever was going on. A beautiful film about the ever-changing nature of life and a people on the mend after the cataclysm of World War 2. This exploration of life's unpredictability and the consequent generational discord is treated solemnly, but with a warm sense of understanding that permeates the screen. The characters are often distraught by the hand they have been dealt, but they seem to have an odd grasp of it. Pain and joy often come hand in hand and Ozu magically captures this push and pull between happiness and sorrow flawlessly. He also succeeds in making these grand statements about change, death, selfishness, guilt, generational disputes, and life's disappointing continuity, without feeling too didactic. On top of these qualities, the way Ozu plays with space is something I have never seen before. Even in the most intimate of places, we can become disoriented. Although we often take the same steps over and over again, life is always a labyrinth of constant change. Like Kurosawa's Stray Dog, Ozu also focuses on the oppression of the heat. From the kids worrying about how to get rid of the parent's burdensome visit, to the Grandparent's trip to a spa meant for a younger generation, each character clutches a fan, attempting to comfort themselves from the uncomfortable atmosphere. It is just one of the many symbols of a people trying to do what they can to cope with such a tentative existence. I can see why this film has been raved about over the many decades since its initial release. It's message is timeless, but the approach feels so fresh. It is an outstanding film and one that should not be missed. A+

Yasujiro Ozu admitted to having been inspired by Leo McCarey's film Make Way for Tomorrow when making his domestic drama masterpiece Tokyo Story. Ozu's style is simplistic in both cinematography and mise en scene - the camera remains still and doesn't move much. Director Yasujiro Ozu quietly examines the outer layer of manners and customs which in turn insulates and isolates a post-war Japanese family. Ozu's solitary knee-high camera position (kneel and shoot) invites us to look up and beyond the polite bows and guarded conversation to the raw emotion that circumstance has forced to the surface. The final farewell scene with sister-in-law Noriko (Setsuko Hara) and youngest daughter Kyoko (Kyoko Kagawa) cries out for human contact yet we are rewarded only with a simple clasping of hands. 

The original title "monogatari" refers to the ancient Japanese literary form, telling us so much more than the English  "Story". Perhaps "Tokyo monogatari" should remain the title in any language. 

Ozu explains very little and offers us everything with this profoundly introspective master work.

Tokyo Story is a beautiful, emotionally devastating film that really shows a side of society that immensely disappoints me. I guess you can say that I developed an instant personal connection to this film, since I've witnessed similar situations. Having to go through the immense lost of my grandfather (who was not only my grandfather, but someone who I can call my dad and my best friend) and knowing for a fact I will be missing him for the rest of my life until I die, I felt greatly disgusted by how a lot of the children in the film treated their parents. I come from a culture where we would NEVER put our parents or grandparents in an old person's home, and we would be more than willing to take care of the people who raised us just the same way they took care of us. If I have to make sacrifices in my job and my me time, then I would make no hesitation, because I LOVE, as well as RESPECT my grandparents/parents. Whatever differences we may have wouldn't even matter and in the end it never did. Not to trying to tell anyone how to live, but I think that showing some compassion and respect towards the people who did a lot for you shows a lot of character. My grandfather may not be with me now, but to know that I did the best that I could to make him happy and not feel alone gives me a sense of comfort in knowing that he was happy.

We unfortunately live in a society where we all are too busy and have places to be, and it sometimes cannot be avoided, but once we deliberately start to distance ourselves from people, then it becomes a problem, especially for the people we should give more time and attention to. This is the me generation, and we are flooded by technology and corporations trying to exploit many aspects of our lives, which dilutes so many of the basic, yet most important aspects of our humanity. A film like this just goes to show that our so called leaders in society don't put much of an effort in influencing us to stay connected or in at least trying to create outlets that will bring us closer as humans. Instead we live in a system that brings out selfishness. While life can be at times unrestrained in its cruelty, at least we have movies like 'Tokyo Story' that shows a sense of humanity in its most raw and purest form. I like to watch films to escape, but especially ones that show an utmost honesty about our society and what 'Tokyo Story' says to me from watching it is that while life is beautiful and still worth living, it can still be immensely disappointing. What makes Tokyo Story such a strong film is that it brings out the harsh reality that exists in our society, in that many people don't put in any effort to maintain the strength of a bond towards their family. What's the point of being part of a family if that person doesn't even have the heart to set things aside to spend time with their parents?

The fact that this film can tug at many people's heart strings goes to show just how much this film is an emotional punch to the gut, in that it shows aspects of human nature that is far reaching and universal. While Japan is one of the many diverse cultures in our world, we still share many of the same issues that can exist in any family relationship. Any film that make me feel this much empathy for its characters is something special and 'Tokyo Story' is that special film.

Considered a cinematic masterpiece, late director Yasujiro Ozu's "Tokyo Story" is a deeply affecting tale of an ageing couple's visit to see their four children.

In black and white and with a usually motionless camera, Ozu followed an unforgettable holiday of father and mother Shukishi and (Chishu Ryu) and Tomi Hirayama (Chieko Higashiyama) from the seaside to the city.

The late film director Yasujiro Ozu once said, "I have formulated my own directing style in my head, proceeding without any unnecessary imitation of others." That's a bold statement, and from nearly any other director I'm aware of, it would be a false one. However, only a few minutes into his film Tokyo Story, I knew the statement was accurate. Nobody makes movies the way Ozu did. The camera work and portrayal of his story is wholly original, and his careful examination of characters is completely refreshing.

Ozu's camera is positioned consistently low and still, providing a frame of an entire room. Characters enter the frame, talk, then leave. End of scene. Often, if there is a close up of a character speaking, they are nearly centred in frame, looking just past the camera. To see western film conventions so completely disregarded was bizarre, but Ozu's incredible story telling quickly dispatched any unease. His themes are so universal, and yet so personal, they did away with any cultural or film style barriers.

Tokyo Story is about an elderly couple, Shukishi (Chishu Ryu) and Tomi (Chieko Higashiyama), who travel a great distance to visit their many children living in Tokyo. They are met with kindness, but are provided with little attention; their children are now adults with busy lives and their own affairs to consider. The eldest son is a doctor of moderate success. Understandably, his work takes precedence over his parents' visit, and all other aspects of his life, much to his own children's distaste. Their oldest daughter is a selfish woman who runs a beauty salon, and does the least to welcome her parents. Their youngest son lives far away from the others, and is the most detached from family affairs. Their youngest daughter is the only child to live at home with them, though she spends much of her time on her education. Another son died in the war, leaving a young widow Noriko (Setsuko Hara), who is the kindest and most generous of the family.

Though it is never outwardly said, much of the family considers this visit to be a burden. They try to pawn off the responsibility of entertaining their parents to one other, which results in the elderly couple spending most of their time resting, for lack of anything to do. The couple is eventually sent to an expensive resort to get them out of the way for a few days. However, the resort is too lively a place, and they return early, much to their eldest daughter's displeasure. She is not a mean person, but she is selfish and claims to be more busy than she is. Such is the case with all the children, save Noriko, who isn't even related by blood.

The many characters of Tokyo Story come alive through their mundane interactions. Ozu brings in his audience by focusing on the universal. We know these characters because we are these characters. We are the ungrateful children, the disappointed parents. We mean no harm, but cause it through our inconsiderate nature. We can never do enough for friends, family, or ourselves, so to varying degrees, we give up over time and fool ourselves into thinking otherwise. We drift from our family. We never meet our potential. We try less, and care less. It takes tragedy for us to realize the selfishness of our ways, and even then, we change little. But are we to blame? Perhaps it's only natural. Tokyo Story doesn't provide answers, only asks us to consider the questions.

But Tokyo Story isn't damning. There is a calmness to the characters, especially the elderly parents, when dealing with all aspects of their lives. The father's demeanour changes little when recollecting fond memories of his long life, or the death of family members. He understands the inevitability of life, and doesn't blame his children for being imperfect or selfish. He is disappointed, but never scornful. He merely appreciates what good comes his way, and accepts all else as a fatalistic routine.

At no point is the movie exploitative. There are no tricks or manipulative conventions. The film presents itself with an authenticity that is as valuable now, if not more so than when the film was released nearly sixty years ago. In an era of film where emotions are often thrown around as carelessly as special effects, Ozu's movies are a reminder of the power of careful, honest storytelling. Few film makers are as honest in their craft as Ozu. 

The week before I watched Tokyo Story, my father was admitted to the hospital. A mass was discovered in his abdomen, but it was a long while before this mass was identified. After news of a particularly difficult night for him, I stayed home from work and decided to take comfort in the discovery of a classic film. As the story's themes presented themselves, I considered stopping the movie. I would not be emotionally prepared for such a challenging film, I thought to myself. However, Tokyo Story gave me great comfort and reassurance, more than any other film I've seen. I have not been the perfect son, but nobody ever has. Ostensibly, the film is talking about how family roles and society in Japan has changed after the end of WWII. That Japan's just not so family-centric and respectful as it had been. Film-schooler and film-buff-wise, Ozu teaches plenty. The most obvious is camera-angle. He continues to shoot from just about six inches off the floor at a rather precise angle that captures the entire length of the characters, a bit of what hangs over their heads, and a good bit of background depth as well. Ozu sometimes identifies location by the pendant lamp that hangs within it. Yet the shot never looks coming to be from as low as it actually is. Ozu here shows a preference for mid-length hall shots that communicate a lot, even when the hall is empty. And Ozu transitions are interesting:  tight, quick, simple and clever. And there's gobs of parallel duality well-executed in this film. Not as much as Hitchcock stuffed into "Vertigo" a few years after this film, but plenty none the less. And here it's sort of more obvious yet still subtle at the same time. Interesting.

RECOMMENDATION: Even though it turns up on a lot of "best ever" lists,  casual film-watchers aren't going to care for it. For one thing, they'll find it just too slow. Serious cinema connoisseurs, however, will patiently observe and learn.

What can I say about a filmmaker like Yasujiro Ozu that has not been said already. Veteran film critic Roger Ebert says about Tokyo Story "It ennobles the cinema. It says, yes, a movie can help us make small steps against our imperfections." 
Ozu's belongs to an exclusive category of minimalist directors who believe that art is a collaboration between God and the artist and the less the artist does the better. Ozu hardly makes cuts, hardly moves his camera, hardly ever changes the angles. In other words, he does very little as a director to 'make' you feel in a certain way yet he manages to make you squirm, make you uncomfortable and drains you emotionally because the characters, the settings, the situations, the dialogues are too close to comfort, they could very well be mirroring our own lives. 
To describe Ozu's handling of his subject as subtle would be a gross understatement. There is no outward conflict, every character is nice to the other yet we as an audience are fully aware of the conflicts beneath the surface, the hatred, the jealousy, the annoyance, the disappointments etc. 

To hail Ozu as one of the finest directors ever would not be overstating it because he takes a subject which is so simple, a story that is hardly original, characters that we have seen in other films and gives us something so deeply layered and complex that at the end of the film, we really are not sure where we stand, what should be done, how to solve these issues.  

Filmmakers use various techniques to make an audience feel closer to the character. Some filmmakers rely on writing, some filmmakers rely on camera angles and close ups. Ozu shuns away these techniques, and instead in some strange metaphysical way takes us right at the centre of the household and experience and live life with them.
